review.title: Bounded Rational Decision-Making in Changing Environments
review.abstract: A perfectly rational decision-maker chooses the best action with the highest utility gain from a set of possible actions. The optimality principles that describe such decision processes do not take into account the computational costs of finding the optimal action. Bounded rational decision-making addresses this problem by specifically trading off information-processing costs and expected utility. Interestingly, a similar trade-off between energy and entropy arises when describing changes in thermodynamic systems. This similarity has been recently used to describe bounded rational agents. Crucially, this framework assumes that the environment does not change while the decision-maker is computing the optimal policy. When this requirement is not fulfilled, the decision-maker will suffer inefficiencies in utility, that arise because the current policy is optimal for an environment in the past. Here we borrow concepts from non-equilibrium thermodynamics to quantify these inefficiencies and illustrate with simulations its relationship with computational resources.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: Classical decision-making theories assume that a perfect rational decision-maker should always choose the option with the best expected benefit, ignoring the computational costs involved in the search for the best option. Experiments in decision-making under uncertainty have shown that they violate these classical theories [1]. As a consequence, many alternative explanations have been proposed to explain this irrational behavior at first glance [2, 3, 4, 5]. A more recent theory of limited rationality for decision-making has been proposed, which takes into account the computational costs of finding the optimal policy. Similar ideas are becoming increasingly interesting and are being used in other areas such as control, robotics, and machine learning [6, 7, 9, 10]. The theory of limited rationality shares the same mathematical framework used in statistical physics to describe changes in thermodynamic systems [3, 11, 12].

sections.heading: 3 Non-equilibrium thermodynamics
sections.text: In this case, the development of a thermodynamic system cannot be described by an equilibrium distribution and then the system is defined which indicates the position and velocity of all particles at a given time (β β = 1). If some external parameters λ of such a system vary over time (e.g. a change in magnetic potential or the position of the wall of a piston), the work is applied to the system and it will develop along a path from an initial state A to a final state B. However, if the change in parameters is carried out endlessly slowly, the whole ensemble of micro-states at a given time can be described by an equilibrium distribution and the work carried out on such a system is equivalent to the free energy difference W = 0. However, if the parameters are applied endlessly to the system, the work depends on the initial microscopic conditions and will be on average higher than the difference in free energy [15].

sections.heading: 4 Inefficiencies due to lag in the policy
sections.text: In this section, we will use the aforementioned non-equilibrium results from statistical physics to describe inefficiencies due to the non-use of an optimal policy. We will consider two simple scenarios in which the change in the supply function ∆ U (x) is applied immediately or in N periods. In both cases, we assume that the active ingredient takes a time step to notice the change in the supply function, then selects a measure from the previous policy and finally calculates the optimal policy immediately. Due to this delay in the optimal policy, the expected benefit that the active ingredient achieves will not be the optimal one (with the free energy difference being the optimal one) and therefore has inefficiencies. We will quantify these inefficiencies in a similar way to work in non-equilibrium thermodynamics.

sections.heading: 4.1 One-step scenario
sections.text: In the one-step scenario, the agent only has to try one action. At the beginning of the process, he uses an initial policy p0 (x) that is optimal for the service function U0 (x) given his resources. Then, there is an external change that changes the service function from U0 (x) to U1 (x) so that it generates a policy p0 (x) from the agent's point of view. Importantly, at the time of this increase in the service function, he is still using his previous policy p0. sections.heading: 5 Simulations
sections.text: In the following simulations, we will illustrate how β the number of steps and resources influence the β derived level of usefulness. Consider the situation in which the agent can choose between two possible measures x {a, b}, and he observes ∆ U (x) = (− 2, 5). However, it is important that this change in usefulness function is made over several periods of time, which allows him to recalculate the optimal policy at the end of each period. In particular, for this simulation, the total number of usage periods is set at N = 4. The initial policy of the agent is only p0 (x) = (0.5, 0.5).In this particular scenario, in Figure 1 (A-C), we show the different values of derived benefit, free energy difference and usage level in relation to the rationality parameter β. In the first phase, the agent uses the policy p0, which does not depend on β, so the usage level for all depends - see Figure 1C.

sections.heading: 6 Conclusions
sections.text: We have adopted concepts from non-equilibrium thermodynamics and applied them to describe inefficiencies in decision-making caused by the use of sub-optimal strategies when the decision-maker is unable to adapt perfectly to a rapidly changing environment. We have shown a corresponding interpretation of the Jarzynski equality in thermodynamics for decision-making, which allows for related variations in the potentially sub-optimal net benefit of a drug versus the optimally attainable benefit due to free energy difference.The most important contribution of this work is to quantify the inefficiencies that occur in limited rational decision-makers when the environment changes faster than the drug can react. These inefficiencies may be irrelevant in slowly changing environments, but of greater importance in rapidly changing environments, as the calculated strategies may differ greatly from the optimal strategies.
